author: Jessica Schladebeck
title: Unarmed Minneapolis man shot and paralyzed by Amtrak officer
text:
Unarmed Minneapolis man shot and paralyzed by Amtrak police officer Unarmed Minneapolis man shot and paralyzed by Amtrak officer Theresa Love Williams, of Robbinsdale, speaks to the media Friday in Minneapolis, in response to the shooting of her nephew, Chad Robertson, by an Amtrak police officer in Chicago. (Aaron Lavinsky/AP) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  22 PM 
An unarmed Minneapolis man was left paralyzed after he was shot by an Amtrak police officer during a layover in Chicago. 
Chad Roberston, 25, was on his way home from a Memphis wedding when he was shot outside Chicago’s Union Station. 
His sister, Nina Robertson, said her brother has been in and out of consciousness since he was shot Wednesday and can’t move or feel anything below his shoulders. 
“He opened his eyes at the hospital, and the first thing he said to me was ‘why did they shoot me? I didn’t do anything,’” she said. “When he found out about his condition from the doctors, he was heartbroken. He just said ‘the police ruined my life.’” 
Man seen threatening people with ax shot and killed by police 
Robertson said after her brother and two of his friends arrived in Chicago, they were instructed to wait inside Union Station and stay warm as they weren’t allowed to enter the bus station. 
There, they were met by two police officers who were rude and aggressive, so they left the station. An unarmed Minneapolis man was shot by an Amtrak police officer. (Leadinglights/Getty Images) 
One of her brother’s friends was forced to return when he realized he left behind his luggage. The officers followed him back outside where they accused the group of smoking marijuana. 
Cops began to search the trio, but when one officer put his hands in Chad Robertson’s pockets, he ran. 
Police fire over 30 shots in car chase from Mount Vernon to Bronx 
“(The officer) yelled ‘If you don’t stop running, I’m going to shoot you,’ and Chad kept running,” said attorney Dennis Hopson, who is representing Robertson and his family. 
Chad Robertson has no criminal record and was unarmed when he was shot, though he was carrying an “insignifcant amount” of marijuana, Hopson said. 
Amtrak spokesman Marc Magliari said the Cook County state’s attorney’s ofice and Chicago police are both looking into the shooting. 
The officers involved are currently on administrative assignment, Magliari said.
